Wood, Ellen Meiksins (2007) Democracy Against Capitalism: Renewing Historical Materialism, New York: Cambridge University Press. APPENDIX A1 Construction of the Democracy Index This Appendix explains in detail the construction of the democracy measure used in the paper.

We do not detect any transition to democracy for Iran and Tanzania, while PS do. In all of these cases we keep our original coding. Our algorithm produces a permanent transition to democracy in South Africa during the early 80s based on Freedom House and Polity. However, PS and all secondary sources agree that the official democratization was in 1994, so we use this date. Gambia and Guyana, which we handled on a case-by-case basis. The particular coding of these countries does not affect our results.37 It is important to note that, in contrast to Papaioannou and Siourounis, we do not impose any Ã¢â¬Åstability criteriaÃ¢â¬Â and also code Ã¢â¬ÅtemporaryÃ¢â¬Â transitions. Though some temporary switches in and out of democracy may be driven by measurement error, focusing only on Ã¢â¬Åpermanent democratizations Ã¢â¬Â (or permanent reversals) would create an obvious bias because the democracy index would be a function of future events, thus potentially correlated with future GDP.

In column 1 we only include four lags of GDP. As anticipated by Figure 1, these four lags are jointly significant. In particular, this specification predicts that democratizations are particularly likely to 37 In particular, we follow most sources and code Cyprus as democratic after 1974. Malaysia is coded as nondemocratic throughout. Guyana is coded as nondemocratic between 1966 and 1990 and democratic in all other years.

As an additional check, we add Ahn and SchmidtÃ¢â¬â¢s (1995) moment conditions. These conditions are nonlinearÃ¢â¬âand this is why they are ignored in many casesÃ¢â¬âbut they follow from the same assumptions required by Arellano and BondÃ¢â¬â¢s baseline GMM estimator. The additional moments take the form (in a balanced panel) E[ÃÂµcT (ÃÂµct Ã¢Ëâ ÃÂµctÃ¢Ëâ1)] = 0Ã¢Ëâ¬t = 2, . . . , T Ã¢Ëâ 1. Columns 6, 7 and 8 present GMM estimators adding these additional Ahn and Schmidt moment conditions to the moment conditions exploited in columns 2, 3 and 4, respectively.41 Comparing the estimates in columns 2-4 with their counterparts in columns 6-8 shows that these additional nonlinear moment conditions improve the fit to GDP dynamics. In particular, GDP persistence in these columns is 0.96, which is closer to our baseline within estimates, but the coefficient of democracy is greater, leading to a larger estimate of the long-run effect on democracy.

Columns 1-4 of Table A10 present the results. 43 We compute standard errors using a Sandwich estimator formula similar to the one in Murphy and Topel (1985) and presented in Stefanski and Boos (2002). This adjusts for the fact that we are using a generated regressor in the second stage.
